context: [7] Given that decline in lung function can occur rapidly and early in employment in flavouring-related obliterative bronchiolitis, , frequent medical surveillance of exposed workers that includes high-quality spirometry and close attention to declines (even within the normal range) is warranted. [8] Furthermore, in the absence of additional toxicological information, an emphasis on exposure reduction through enhanced ventilation and use of respiratory protection is prudent. [1] Among current flavouring manufacturing workers, some symptoms and diagnoses were more common than expected, while spirometric abnormalities were not in excess. [2] Symptoms, lung function abnormalities and average lung function values differed by exposure. [3] These differences could not be explained by age, smoking status or employment at another flavouring plant, suggesting that they reflect outcomes of occupational exposures at the facility. [4] These findings are most consistent with undiagnosed or subclinical obliterative bronchiolitis in this workforce and indicate that further efforts to lower exposures to flavouring chemicals, including diacetyl substitutes, are warranted. [1] Objectives: Four diacetyl workers were found to have bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome.
